question: 40 year old male with newly diagnosed moderate UC and articular extraintestinal manifestations
gt_reason: IFX is ideal choice as biologically naïve with EIM.
prompt:
System:
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
pro1: Vedolizumab is an anti-integrin antibody that has shown efficacy in treating moderate to severe UC. It is gut-selective, which means it specifically targets the gut immune system, potentially reducing systemic side effects. It may be a good choice for a newly diagnosed patient.
cons1: However, due to its gut-selective nature, Vedolizumab may not be as effective in managing extraintestinal manifestations such as articular symptoms. Additionally, as with any biologic therapy, there is a risk of side effects including infections.
pro2: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in treating both UC and extraintestinal manifestations, including articular symptoms. It may provide a more comprehensive treatment approach for this patient.
cons2: However, Infliximab is administered via infusion, which may be less convenient for some patients. There is also a risk of side effects, including serious infections and potential for primary nonresponse or secondary loss of response over time.

INTRODUCTION
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity,
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

text: Burr et al.

5 of 45
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS

What is already known about this subject
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe.
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed
for this indication.
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety,
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these.

What are the new findings
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

Our results confirm that all available drugs, other than adalimumab 160/160mg,

treatment of moderate to severe UC, across all endpoints studied at 6 to 14 weeks. All drugs

title: Efficacy of biological therapies and small molecules in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis: systematic review and network meta-analysis

filename: gutjnl-2021-326390R2 CLEAN.pdf

page: 27

text: Burr et al.

27 of 45
DISCUSSION
We conducted a contemporaneous systematic review and network meta-analysis of
biological therapies and small molecules for moderate to severely active UC. This has
incorporated data from 28 RCTs and over 12,500 patients. Overall, in terms of clinical
remission and clinical response at 6 to 14 weeks, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked first in all
patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-TNF-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these
drugs. In terms of endoscopic improvement infliximab 10mg/kg ranked first, followed by
upadacitinib 45mg o.d., and infliximab 5mg/kg. However, again upadacitinib 45mg o.d.
ranked first in patients previously exposed to anti-TNF-α therapies, and in patients who were
anti-TNF-α naïve. In terms of safety, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked last for total number of
adverse events, and ustekinumab 130mg first. However, none of the drugs studied were more

Human: question
pro1: Upadacitinib has been found to be potentially more efficacious for moderate to severely active UC than existing licensed therapies. It has shown high efficacy in achieving clinical response, clinical remission, and endoscopic response over 1 year for moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis patients. It is also effective in patients who are new to anti-TNF-α therapies.
cons1: Despite its efficacy, upadacitinib has been associated with a higher number of adverse events compared to other drugs. As the patient is elderly, this could potentially increase the risk of side effects.
pro2: Infliximab has been found to be effective in terms of endoscopic improvement in patients with moderate to severe UC. It is also effective in patients who are new to anti-TNF-α therapies.
cons2: Infliximab is a biologic therapy and requires parenteral administration, which may not be convenient for all patients. Additionally, there can be issues with primary nonresponse, secondary loss of response, and immunogenicity.

gt_reason: Testing 2nd line treatment to patients previously exposed to anti-TNFa
prompt:

You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.

- Prior failure to Vedolizumab

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Ustekinumab and Tofacitinib.

1. Ustekinumab:
   - Advantages: Ustekinumab is an anti-interleukin-12/23 antibody that has been ranked highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists like Infliximab for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also associated with a lower risk of infections.
   - Disadvantages: As with any medication, there is a risk of side effects, including serious infections, allergic reactions, and liver damage. It may also not be as effective in patients who have failed multiple other biologic therapies.

2. Tofacitinib:
   - Advantages: Tofacitinib is a Janus kinase inhibitor that has also been ranked highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement. It is an oral medication, which may be more convenient for some patients compared to injectable or intravenous therapies.
   - Disadvantages: Tofacitinib carries a risk of serious side effects, including serious infections, cancer, and blood clots. It may also increase cholesterol levels and liver enzyme levels, which need to be monitored.

Please note that the choice of therapy should be individualized based on the patient's overall health, lifestyle, and preferences.

Introduction
Ulcerative colitis is a chronic, idiopathic, potentially
disabling condition that is clinically characterised
by bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus.1
Ulcerative colitis most commonly presents during the
third and fifth decades of life, and is associated with an
impaired health-related quality of life and considerable
economic burden.2,3
Nearly 20 years ago, the advent of anti-tumour necrosis
factor biologics (eg, infliximab, adalimumab, and
golimumab) revolutionised therapeutics for ulcerative
colitis, enabling better disease control in terms of
increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission,
and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality
of life. Biologics with other targets were later approved
for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis,

meta-analysis included 14 induction of remission trials, recruiting almost 5500 patients,
although the Japanese trial of infliximab versus placebo in 208 patients reported by
Kobayashi et al. was not included.[42] In contrast to these previous network meta-analyses,
our results provide hope that some novel drugs, which are likely to come to market soon, are
potentially more efficacious for moderate to severely active UC than existing licensed
therapies.
Our results confirm that all available drugs, other than adalimumab 160/160mg,

In a systematic review and network meta-analysis, we found inﬂiximab to be ranked highest in

INTRODUCTION
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity,
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel
source9:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.

Human: question
pro1: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets inflammation in the gut, reducing systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe UC. As a new patient, this could be a good first-line biologic therapy. Additionally, given the patient's background of congestive cardiac failure, a drug with less systemic effects may be beneficial.
cons1: Vedolizumab requires intravenous administration, which can be inconvenient for some patients. It may also take several weeks to see an effect. Side effects can include headache, joint pain, nausea, and fever. There is also a risk of serious infections.
pro2: Ustekinumab is another biologic that can be used in the treatment of moderate to severe UC. It works by blocking a specific protein (interleukin-12 and -23) involved in inflammation. It can be administered subcutaneously after the initial dose, which may be more convenient for the patient.
cons2: Ustekinumab may not be as effective as other biologics in inducing remission in UC. Side effects can include upper respiratory infections, fatigue, and headache. There is also a risk of serious infections and it may take several weeks to see an effect.

STUDY HIGHLIGHTS

What is already known about this subject
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe.
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed
for this indication.
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety,
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these.

What are the new findings
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

Human: question
pro1: Ustekinumab is a good choice for this patient as it has shown efficacy in treating both ulcerative colitis and psoriasis, which are both present in this patient. It is also well-tolerated and ranked first in terms of safety in a study.
cons1: While Ustekinumab is generally safe, it may still cause side effects such as injection site reactions, upper respiratory infections, and in rare cases, serious infections. It is also administered via injection, which may not be preferred by some patients.
pro2: Vedolizumab is another option for this patient. It is specifically designed to treat ulcerative colitis and has shown efficacy in achieving clinical response and remission. It is also generally well-tolerated.
cons2: Vedolizumab may not be as effective in treating psoriasis, which is also present in this patient. It is also administered via infusion, which requires hospital visits and may not be convenient for some patients. Side effects may include headache, joint pain, nausea, and fever.

text: Burr et al.

27 of 45
DISCUSSION
We conducted a contemporaneous systematic review and network meta-analysis of
biological therapies and small molecules for moderate to severely active UC. This has
incorporated data from 28 RCTs and over 12,500 patients. Overall, in terms of clinical
remission and clinical response at 6 to 14 weeks, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked first in all
patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-TNF-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these
drugs. In terms of endoscopic improvement infliximab 10mg/kg ranked first, followed by
upadacitinib 45mg o.d., and infliximab 5mg/kg. However, again upadacitinib 45mg o.d.
ranked first in patients previously exposed to anti-TNF-α therapies, and in patients who were
anti-TNF-α naïve. In terms of safety, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked last for total number of
adverse events, and ustekinumab 130mg first. However, none of the drugs studied were more

The advanced therapeutic armamentarium for adults
with moderately to severely active UC is rapidly evolving.
For over 20 years, biologics targeting specific inflamma-
tory pathways have been the mainstay, beginning with those
targeting tumor necrosis alpha (TNFi; eg, infliximab [INF],
adalimumab [ADA], and golimumab [GOL]) followed by
biologics with other modes of action (eg, vedolizumab [VED]
and ustekinumab [UST]). However, treatment limitations for
moderately to severely active UC remain, including primary
nonresponse, secondary loss of response, immunogenicity, and
parenteral administration.2 To overcome these limitations,
there has been increasing interest in small molecule drugs
(SMDs), which can be orally administered and lack immu-
nogenicity.3 Of particular interest are SMDs that inhibit the

The International Organization for the Study of Inﬂam-

CD and UC severity into mild-, moderate-, and high-risk
groups based on phenotype and other characteristics.59,60
In CD, the presence of large or deep mucosal lesions on
endoscopy or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), history of
a ﬁstula, abscess, or intestinal resection are predictors of
worse outcomes.59,60 In a prospective population-based
inception cohort of 213 patients with CD, penetrating
behavior was associated with a higher risk of progression to
perianal disease (HR, 5.65; 95% CI, 2.65–12.03) and was a
risk factor for resection (HR, 3.92; 95% CI, 1.86–8.67) and
hospitalization (HR, 1.01; 95% CI, 1.00–1.01).16 Ileal and
upper gastrointestinal disease location and extensive dis-
ease are also markers of severe disease.61 Cigarette smoking

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Infliximab and Vedolizumab.

1. Infliximab:
   - Advantages: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in treating both ulcerative colitis and ankylosing spondylitis. It can help to reduce inflammation and achieve remission in both conditions.
   - Disadvantages: Infliximab can have side effects including increased risk of infections due to its immunosuppressive effect. It can also cause allergic reactions, and some patients may develop antibodies to the drug, reducing its effectiveness over time.

2. Vedolizumab:
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, which means it specifically targets the gut and may have fewer systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
   - Disadvantages: Vedolizumab may not be as effective in treating ankylosing spondylitis as it is in treating ulcerative colitis. It also carries a risk of infections and other side effects such as headache, joint pain, nausea, and fever.

It's important to note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's specific symptoms, overall health, and response to previous treatments. The patient should also be closely monitored for side effects and response to the treatment.

filename: gutjnl-2021-326390R2 CLEAN.pdf

page: 5

text: Burr et al.

5 of 45
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS

What is already known about this subject
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe.
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed
for this indication.
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety,
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these.

What are the new findings
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

Human: question
pro1: Infliximab is a TNF antagonist that has revolutionized therapeutics for ulcerative colitis. It has been shown to increase rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, and corticosteroid-free remission, and improve quality of life. It is also a good option for patients who have lost response to vedolizumab.
cons1: Infliximab has several limitations including limited efficacy in some patients, primary non-response, secondary loss of response, and immunogenicity. It may also have side effects such as infections, allergic reactions, and potential for developing antibodies against the drug.
pro2: Ustekinumab is an anti-interleukin-12/23 antibody that can be used in patients who have failed treatment with vedolizumab. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
cons2: Ustekinumab may not work for everyone and some patients may experience side effects such as infections, allergic reactions, and fatigue. It is also usually considered as a second-line therapy, so it may not be the first choice for some patients.

title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

text: (prior exposure to tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for treatment of moder-
ate to severely active ulcerative colitis in a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
METHODS:
We searched publication databases through September 30, 2019, for randomized trials of
adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis treated with TNF antagonists, vedolizumab,
tofacitinib, or ustekinumab, as ﬁrst-line or second-line agents, compared with placebo or
another active agent. Efﬁcacy outcomes were induction and maintenance of remission and
endoscopic improvement; safety outcomes were serious adverse events and infections. We
performed a ﬁxed-effects network meta-analysis using the frequentist approach, and calculated
odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CI values. Agents were ranked using surface under the cumulative
ranking (SUCRA) probabilities. Overall quality of evidence was rated using GRADE (Grading of
Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation).

question: 28 year old woman who has severe extensive ulcerative colitis and has a history of lymphoma which was treated 4 years ago
gt_reason: Anti-TNFs and JAK inhs have associations/concerns with malignancies
prompt:
System:
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, she has severe extensive ulcerative colitis and a history of lymphoma. Given her history of lymphoma, it would be prudent to avoid anti-TNF agents due to their potential risk of reactivating malignancies. Therefore, the top two choices of biological drugs for this patient would be Vedolizumab and Ustekinumab.

1. Vedolizumab:
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets the gut and has less systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
   - Disadvantages: Some patients may not respond to Vedolizumab or may lose response over time. It may also increase the risk of infections.

2. Ustekinumab:
   - Advantages: Ustekinumab is effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and has a good safety profile. It works by inhibiting interleukin (IL)-12 and IL-23, which are involved in inflammatory and immune responses.
   - Disadvantages: Ustekinumab may not work for everyone and some patients may lose response over time. It may also increase the risk of infections and has a higher cost.

It's important to discuss these options with the patient, considering her personal preferences, lifestyle, and potential side effects of each treatment.

Introduction
Ulcerative colitis is a chronic, idiopathic, potentially
disabling condition that is clinically characterised
by bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus.1
Ulcerative colitis most commonly presents during the
third and fifth decades of life, and is associated with an
impaired health-related quality of life and considerable
economic burden.2,3
Nearly 20 years ago, the advent of anti-tumour necrosis
factor biologics (eg, infliximab, adalimumab, and
golimumab) revolutionised therapeutics for ulcerative
colitis, enabling better disease control in terms of
increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission,
and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality
of life. Biologics with other targets were later approved
for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis,

part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates

usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse

You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).

- Prior failure to Vedolizumab

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Vedolizumab and Ustekinumab.

1. Vedolizumab:
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets inflammation in the gut, reducing systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also less likely to cause infections compared to other biologics.
   - Disadvantages: Vedolizumab may take longer to show effects compared to other biologics. It is administered via intravenous infusion, which may not be convenient for all patients. Some patients may also experience side effects such as headache, joint pain, nausea, or fever.

2. Ustekinumab:
   - Advantages: Ustekinumab is primarily used for the treatment of psoriasis but has shown efficacy in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also used in treating multiple sclerosis, which the patient has, potentially providing dual benefits.
   - Disadvantages: Ustekinumab may increase the risk of infections. It is also administered via injection, which may not be convenient for all patients. Some patients may experience side effects such as fatigue, headache, or skin rash.

It's important to note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's overall health status, preference, and potential side effects. The patient should also be closely monitored for any adverse effects during the treatment.

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the patient is under maintenance for ulcerative colitis and has a history of malignant melanoma. The patient's age is also a factor to consider in the treatment plan.

Given this information, the top two choices of biological drugs could be:

1. Vedolizumab: This is a gut-selective immunosuppressant that could be a good option for this patient.

Advantages:
- It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
- It is gut-selective and does not have systemic immunosuppressive effects, which could be beneficial for a patient with a history of malignant melanoma.

Disadvantages:
- It may take longer to see the effects of the drug compared to other treatments.
- It requires intravenous administration, which may not be convenient for all patients.

2. Ustekinumab: This is an interleukin (IL)-12 and IL-23 inhibitor.

Advantages:
- It has been shown to be effective in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
- It may be a good option for patients who have not responded to or cannot use other treatments.

Disadvantages:
- It requires initial intravenous administration, followed by subcutaneous injections, which may not be convenient for all patients.
- There is a risk of serious infections and malignancies with ustekinumab, which may not be suitable for a patient with a history of malignant melanoma.

Please note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's overall health, preferences, and potential response to treatment. It's also important to monitor the patient's condition closely during treatment.

INTRODUCTION
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity,
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

Ulcerative colitis is a chronic, idiopathic, potentially
disabling condition that is clinically characterised
by bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus.1
Ulcerative colitis most commonly presents during the
third and fifth decades of life, and is associated with an
impaired health-related quality of life and considerable
economic burden.2,3
Nearly 20 years ago, the advent of anti-tumour necrosis
factor biologics (eg, infliximab, adalimumab, and
golimumab) revolutionised therapeutics for ulcerative
colitis, enabling better disease control in terms of
increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission,
and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality
of life. Biologics with other targets were later approved
for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis,

text: Burr et al.

5 of 45
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS

What is already known about this subject
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe.
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed
for this indication.
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety,
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these.

What are the new findings
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

Human: question
raw_answer:
Given the patient's successful induction with vedolizumab, it would be reasonable to continue vedolizumab as a maintenance therapy. This is supported by the data suggesting that vedolizumab is effective for long-term maintenance of clinical remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.

Another option could be infliximab, which has been shown to be effective in maintaining clinical remission and endoscopic improvement in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. However, no significant differences were observed between infliximab and vedolizumab in terms of efficacy.

Here are the top two choices:

1. Vedolizumab
   - Advantages: The patient has already had a successful induction with vedolizumab, suggesting she may respond well to it as a maintenance therapy. Vedolizumab has been shown to be effective for long-term maintenance of clinical remission.
   - Disadvantages: As with any medication, there is a risk of side effects, which can include headache, joint pain, nausea, or fever. There is also a risk of serious infections.

2. Infliximab
   - Advantages: Infliximab has been shown to be effective in maintaining clinical remission and endoscopic improvement in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
   - Disadvantages: Infliximab can have side effects, including risk of serious infections. It may also cause infusion reactions.

Please note that the choice of therapy should be individualized based on the patient's specific circumstances and preferences, and in consultation with their healthcare provider.

text: molecule drugs as induction or maintenance therapies for patients with moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis were
included. Phase 2 RCTs were excluded because of their small sample sizes and inclusion of doses not further explored
in phase 3 RCTs. Summary data from intention-to-treat analyses were extracted from included reports by JSL and PAO.
The primary outcome was the induction of clinical remission. A network meta-analysis was done under the frequentist
framework, obtaining pairwise odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CIs. The surface under the cumulative ranking (SUCRA)
was used to rank the included agents for each outcome. Higher SUCRA scores correlate with better efficacy, whereas
lower SUCRA scores correlate with better safety. Maintenance data on efficacy for treat-straight-through and
randomised responder trials are also presented. This study is registered with PROSPERO, CRD42021225329.

Discussion
We reviewed available efficacy and safety data from RCTs
of biologics and small molecule drugs (approved or in a
late stage of development) for induction and maintenance
treatment of patients with moderate-to-severe ulcerative
colitis. All small molecule drugs and approved biologics,
except filgotinib 100 mg, were significantly better than
placebo in terms of inducing clinical remission and
endoscopic improvement. A novel finding of this study
was that upadacitinib ranked highest for the induction of
clinical remission and endoscopic improvement, and
was notably superior for these outcomes to all other
interventions in our network meta-analysis. Infliximab
ranked second for both outcomes. Regarding safety,
vedolizumab was still ranked as the safest drug in
terms of adverse events and serious adverse events, as

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the patient has moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and has developed a loss of response to Infliximab due to antibody formation. This suggests that the patient has had prior exposure to anti-TNF agents and has failed to respond to Infliximab.

Given this, the top two choices of biological drugs for this patient would be Ustekinumab and Tofacitinib.

1. Ustekinumab:
- Advantages: Ustekinumab is an anti-interleukin-12/23 antibody and has been ranked highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement. It has a different mechanism of action compared to anti-TNF agents, which may be beneficial for patients who have developed antibodies to anti-TNF agents.
- Disadvantages: Ustekinumab may have limited efficacy in some patients and there is a risk of primary non-response or secondary loss of response. There is also a risk of immunogenicity, similar to other biologics.

2. Tofacitinib:
- Advantages: Tofacitinib is a Janus kinase inhibitor and has also been ranked highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement. It is a small molecule, not a biologic, which means it is less likely to provoke an immune response and lead to the formation of antibodies.
- Disadvantages: Tofacitinib has been associated with an increased risk of serious infections compared to other drugs. It may also have limited efficacy in some patients and there is a risk of primary non-response or secondary loss of response.

Introduction
Ulcerative colitis is a chronic, idiopathic, potentially
disabling condition that is clinically characterised
by bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus.1
Ulcerative colitis most commonly presents during the
third and fifth decades of life, and is associated with an
impaired health-related quality of life and considerable
economic burden.2,3
Nearly 20 years ago, the advent of anti-tumour necrosis
factor biologics (eg, infliximab, adalimumab, and
golimumab) revolutionised therapeutics for ulcerative
colitis, enabling better disease control in terms of
increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission,
and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality
of life. Biologics with other targets were later approved
for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis,

STUDY HIGHLIGHTS

What is already known about this subject
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe.
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed
for this indication.
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety,
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these.

What are the new findings
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

source5:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 1

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.

title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

page: 0

text: (prior exposure to tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for treatment of moder-
ate to severely active ulcerative colitis in a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
METHODS:
We searched publication databases through September 30, 2019, for randomized trials of
adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis treated with TNF antagonists, vedolizumab,
tofacitinib, or ustekinumab, as ﬁrst-line or second-line agents, compared with placebo or
another active agent. Efﬁcacy outcomes were induction and maintenance of remission and
endoscopic improvement; safety outcomes were serious adverse events and infections. We
performed a ﬁxed-effects network meta-analysis using the frequentist approach, and calculated
odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CI values. Agents were ranked using surface under the cumulative
ranking (SUCRA) probabilities. Overall quality of evidence was rated using GRADE (Grading of
Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation).
RESULTS:

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, she has moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and also suffers from rheumatoid arthritis. Considering her age and the presence of an extraintestinal manifestation (rheumatoid arthritis), the following two biological drugs could be considered:

1. Infliximab
2. Adalimumab

Here are the pros and cons of each:

Infliximab:
- Advantages: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It can also be beneficial for patients with rheumatoid arthritis, which the patient also suffers from.
- Disadvantages: Infliximab is administered intravenously, which may not be convenient for all patients. It can also cause side effects such as infections, allergic reactions, and liver damage.

Adalimumab:
- Advantages: Adalimumab is another TNF-alpha inhibitor that can be used in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and rheumatoid arthritis. It is administered subcutaneously, which some patients may find more convenient than intravenous administration.
- Disadvantages: Adalimumab can cause side effects such as infections, allergic reactions, and liver damage. It may also not be as effective as infliximab in some patients.

It's important to note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's specific circumstances, including her overall health, the severity of her symptoms, and her personal preferences. The patient should also be closely monitored for side effects during treatment.

INTRODUCTION
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity,
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Vedolizumab and Adalimumab.

1. Vedolizumab:
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets inflammation in the gut, potentially leading to fewer systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
   - Disadvantages: Vedolizumab is administered via intravenous infusion, which requires hospital visits. However, after the initial doses, the infusions are only needed every 8 weeks. Some patients may experience side effects such as headache, joint pain, nausea, or fever.

2. Adalimumab:
   - Advantages: Adalimumab is a self-administered subcutaneous injection, which can be done at home, providing convenience for the patient. It has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis, and can lead to remission in some patients.
   - Disadvantages: Adalimumab is a systemic immunosuppressant, which can potentially lead to more side effects, including serious infections. Regular monitoring is required to ensure the drug is working and not causing harmful effects.

Please note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's specific circumstances and preferences, and in consultation with their healthcare provider.

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Infliximab and Tofacitinib.

1. Infliximab:
   - Advantages: Infliximab has been found to be highly effective in inducing remission and endoscopic improvement in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is especially effective in biologic-naïve patients.
   - Disadvantages: Infliximab has a risk of causing serious infections. It may also cause immunogenicity, leading to a secondary loss of response.

2. Tofacitinib:
   - Advantages: Tofacitinib has been ranked highly in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement. It is a small molecule and not a biologic, which may reduce the risk of immunogenicity.
   - Disadvantages: Tofacitinib may have a higher risk of serious infections compared to other treatments. It may also have other side effects such as increased cholesterol levels, increased risk of blood clots, and decreased blood cell counts.

Please note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's overall health, comorbidities, and preferences. It is also important to consider the patient's prior response to treatments and any potential contraindications.

title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 0

text: (prior exposure to tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for treatment of moder-
ate to severely active ulcerative colitis in a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
METHODS:
We searched publication databases through September 30, 2019, for randomized trials of
adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis treated with TNF antagonists, vedolizumab,
tofacitinib, or ustekinumab, as ﬁrst-line or second-line agents, compared with placebo or
another active agent. Efﬁcacy outcomes were induction and maintenance of remission and
endoscopic improvement; safety outcomes were serious adverse events and infections. We
performed a ﬁxed-effects network meta-analysis using the frequentist approach, and calculated
odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CI values. Agents were ranked using surface under the cumulative
ranking (SUCRA) probabilities. Overall quality of evidence was rated using GRADE (Grading of
Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation).

text: Burr et al.

5 of 45
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS

What is already known about this subject
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe.
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed
for this indication.
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety,
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these.

What are the new findings
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.
source7:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 1

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Infliximab and Vedolizumab.

1. Infliximab:
   - Advantages: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also effective in treating extraintestinal manifestations of UC, such as spondylarthritis.
   - Disadvantages: Infliximab can cause serious side effects, including infections (such as tuberculosis), lymphoma, and other cancers. Patients may also develop antibodies to infliximab, which can reduce its effectiveness.

2. Vedolizumab:
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, which means it specifically targets the gut and is less likely to cause systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
   - Disadvantages: Vedolizumab may not be as effective in treating extraintestinal manifestations of UC, such as spondylarthritis. It can also cause side effects, including headache, joint pain, nausea, and fever. In rare cases, it can cause serious infections, liver problems, and allergic reactions.

text: Burr et al.

5 of 45
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS

What is already known about this subject
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe.
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed
for this indication.
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety,
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these.

What are the new findings
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

question: 42 year-old woman with moderate ulcerative colitis on azathioprine and not responding to therapy
gt_reason: Combination therapy
prompt:
System:
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, she has moderate ulcerative colitis and is not responding to azathioprine therapy. Considering this, the top two choices of biological drugs for her could be Infliximab and Vedolizumab.

1. Infliximab:
   - Advantages: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It can also improve the quality of life of patients.
   - Disadvantages: Infliximab can cause serious side effects including infections, allergic reactions, and potentially an increased risk of lymphoma. It may also lead to primary non-response or secondary loss of response over time.

2. Vedolizumab:
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, which means it specifically targets the gut and spares the rest of the body from immunosuppression. This can potentially lead to fewer systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
   - Disadvantages: Vedolizumab may take longer to work compared to other biologics. It can also cause side effects such as headache, joint pain, nausea, and fever. In rare cases, it can cause serious infections.

Please note that the choice of therapy should be individualized based on the patient's specific circumstances, including disease severity, comorbidities, and personal preferences. It's also important to consider the cost and availability of these medications.

variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the

some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates

- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance

- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Infliximab and Adalimumab.

1. Infliximab:
   - Advantages: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in treating severe ulcerative colitis. It is also one of the few agents that has been evaluated in a large, dedicated placebo-randomized trial for fistulating disease, showing promising results.
   - Disadvantages: Infliximab can have side effects including infections, allergic reactions, and potential liver damage. It also requires intravenous administration, which can be inconvenient for some patients.

2. Adalimumab:
   - Advantages: Adalimumab is another TNF-alpha inhibitor that can be used in the treatment of severe ulcerative colitis. It is administered subcutaneously, which may be more convenient for some patients compared to intravenous administration.
   - Disadvantages: Similar to Infliximab, Adalimumab can have side effects including infections, allergic reactions, and potential liver damage. Its efficacy in treating fistulating disease is not as well-studied as Infliximab.

Please note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's overall health, lifestyle, and preferences. It is also important to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

INTRODUCTION
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity,
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

Ulcerative colitis is a chronic, idiopathic, potentially
disabling condition that is clinically characterised
by bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus.1
Ulcerative colitis most commonly presents during the

increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission,
and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality
of life. Biologics with other targets were later approved
for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis,

System:
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.

- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance

- Prior failure to Vedolizumab

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the patient is under maintenance for ulcerative colitis and has a history of prostate cancer. The patient's age is also a significant factor to consider in the treatment plan.

Given this information, the top two choices of biological drugs could be Vedolizumab and Ustekinumab.

1. Vedolizumab:
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets the gut and has less systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also generally well-tolerated in older patients.
   - Disadvantages: The main disadvantage of Vedolizumab is that it may take longer to work compared to other treatments. It also requires intravenous administration, which may not be convenient for all patients.

2. Ustekinumab:
   - Advantages: Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the p40 subunit of interleukin (IL)-12 and IL-23, cytokines involved in inflammatory and immune responses. It has been shown to be effective in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It can be administered subcutaneously after the initial intravenous dose, which can be more convenient for patients.
   - Disadvantages: Potential side effects of Ustekinumab include upper respiratory infections, fatigue, and headache. There is also a potential risk of serious infections, malignancy, and cardiovascular events, which may be a concern given the patient's age and history of prostate cancer.

It's important to note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's overall health, preferences, and potential for drug interactions. The patient's oncologist should also be consulted due to the history of prostate cancer.

text: Burr et al.

5 of 45
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS

What is already known about this subject
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe.
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed
for this indication.
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety,
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these.

What are the new findings
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

question: 25 year-old man with extensive moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and primary sclerosing cholangitis with decompensated cirrhosis.
gt_reason: Low/No evidence here
prompt:
System:
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================

summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Vedolizumab and Ustekinumab.

1. Vedolizumab:
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, which means it specifically targets the gut and has less systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It may also be a safer option for this patient given his decompensated cirrhosis, as it has less hepatic metabolism compared to other drugs.
   - Disadvantages: Vedolizumab may take longer to show effects compared to other biologics. It also requires intravenous administration, which may not be convenient for all patients.

2. Ustekinumab:
   - Advantages: Ustekinumab is effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and can be administered subcutaneously after the initial intravenous dose. It has a different mechanism of action compared to other biologics, targeting interleukin-12 and -23, which may be beneficial if the patient has not responded to other treatments.
   - Disadvantages: Ustekinumab may not be as effective in patients with extensive disease. It also requires initial intravenous administration, which can be inconvenient. The safety of Ustekinumab in patients with decompensated cirrhosis is not well studied.

Please note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's overall health, lifestyle, and preferences. It is also important to monitor the patient's liver function closely due to his decompensated cirrhosis.

gt_reason: Infliximab and Tofacitinib have the quickest response
prompt:
System:
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.

summaries

Human: question
pro1: Infliximab is a well-established treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission, reducing hospitalizations, and improving quality of life. It is also known for its rapid onset of action, which aligns with the patient's priority for a quick response to treatment.
cons1: Infliximab is administered via intravenous infusion, which may be inconvenient for some patients. It can also cause side effects such as increased risk of infections, allergic reactions, and potential for development of antibodies against the drug, which can decrease its effectiveness over time.
pro2: Upadacitinib has been shown to be highly efficacious in achieving clinical response and remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis, even in those who have had prior exposure to anti-TNF therapies. It is taken orally, which may be more convenient for some patients.
cons2: While Upadacitinib has shown promising results, it is a relatively new drug and long-term safety data is still being collected. Potential side effects include increased risk of infections, changes in blood counts, and potential liver damage.

text: Burr et al.

5 of 45
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS

What is already known about this subject
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe.
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed
for this indication.
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety,
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these.

What are the new findings
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

Human: question
pro1: Ustekinumab has been shown to be effective in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists, which includes tofacitinib. It is also generally well-tolerated with a good safety profile.
cons1: Ustekinumab may not work for everyone and it can take several weeks to see an improvement in symptoms. Side effects can include respiratory infections, headache, and fatigue. There is also a risk of serious infections and allergic reactions.
pro2: Upadacitinib has been ranked first in terms of clinical remission and response in all patients, including those previously exposed to anti-TNF therapies like tofacitinib. It has shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials.
cons2: While upadacitinib has a similar safety profile to other advanced therapies, potential side effects can include upper respiratory tract infections, nausea, and acne. There is also a risk of serious infections, malignancies, and thrombosis.

text: (prior exposure to tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for treatment of moder-
ate to severely active ulcerative colitis in a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
METHODS:
We searched publication databases through September 30, 2019, for randomized trials of
adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis treated with TNF antagonists, vedolizumab,
tofacitinib, or ustekinumab, as ﬁrst-line or second-line agents, compared with placebo or
another active agent. Efﬁcacy outcomes were induction and maintenance of remission and
endoscopic improvement; safety outcomes were serious adverse events and infections. We
performed a ﬁxed-effects network meta-analysis using the frequentist approach, and calculated
odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CI values. Agents were ranked using surface under the cumulative
ranking (SUCRA) probabilities. Overall quality of evidence was rated using GRADE (Grading of
Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation).

source9:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 1

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the patient is a new patient with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and extraintestinal manifestations (pyoderma gangrenosum). Considering the patient's age and disease severity, biological drugs would be a suitable treatment option.

Here are two top choices of biological drugs for this patient:

1. Infliximab
   - Advantages: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It can also help manage extraintestinal manifestations like pyoderma gangrenosum. Infliximab has a rapid onset of action, which can be beneficial in patients with severe symptoms.
   - Disadvantages: Infliximab can cause serious side effects, including infections, lymphoma, and other cancers. It can also cause infusion reactions, which can be severe. Some patients may develop antibodies to infliximab, which can reduce its effectiveness.

2. Vedolizumab
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, which means it specifically targets the gut and is less likely to cause systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
   - Disadvantages: Vedolizumab may not be as effective in managing extraintestinal manifestations like pyoderma gangrenosum. It also has a slower onset of action compared to TNF-alpha inhibitors. Some patients may experience side effects like headache, joint pain, nausea, or fever.

These are general pros and cons, and the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's specific circumstances and preferences. The patient should be closely monitored for response to treatment and potential side effects.

  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the

behavior was associated with a higher risk of progression to
perianal disease (HR, 5.65; 95% CI, 2.65–12.03) and was a
risk factor for resection (HR, 3.92; 95% CI, 1.86–8.67) and
hospitalization (HR, 1.01; 95% CI, 1.00–1.01).16 Ileal and
upper gastrointestinal disease location and extensive dis-
ease are also markers of severe disease.61 Cigarette smoking

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the patient is under maintenance for moderate to severe distal ulcerative colitis and has optic neuritis. The patient's age is 58 and she is a woman. There is no information about prior response to Infliximab, prior failure to Anti-TNF agents, prior failure to Vedolizumab, pregnancy, extraintestinale manifestations, or pouchitis.

Given this information, the top two choices of biological drugs could be:

1. Vedolizumab
Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets inflammation in the gut and is less likely to cause systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
Disadvantages: Vedolizumab may take longer to work than other biologics. It also requires intravenous administration, which can be inconvenient. Some patients may experience side effects such as headache, joint pain, nausea, or fever.

2. Ustekinumab
Advantages: Ustekinumab is generally well-tolerated and has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It works by blocking certain proteins that cause inflammation.
Disadvantages: Ustekinumab requires initial intravenous administration followed by subcutaneous injections, which some patients may find inconvenient or uncomfortable. Potential side effects include upper respiratory infections, fatigue, and headache.

Please note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's specific condition, preferences, and potential for side effects. It's also important to consider the patient's optic neuritis when choosing a treatment, as some medications may exacerbate this condition. Always consult with a healthcare provider before starting any new medication.

text: Burr et al.

5 of 45
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS

What is already known about this subject
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe.
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed
for this indication.
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety,
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these.

What are the new findings
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

question: 55 year-old man with moderate to severe extensive ulcerative colitis and colonic polyps with high grade dysplasia found 2 years ago.
gt_reason: ?? No idea
prompt:
System:
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the patient is not new and is under maintenance. The patient's age is 55 years old and has a history of colonic polyps with high-grade dysplasia. There is no information provided about prior response to Infliximab, prior failure to Anti-TNF agents, prior failure to Vedolizumab, pregnancy, extraintestinal manifestations, or pouchitis.

Given this information, the top two choices of biological drugs for this patient could be:

1. Infliximab
2. Vedolizumab

Here are the pros and cons of these two choices:

Infliximab:
- Advantages: Infliximab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It can also improve quality of life and reduce the need for hospitalization and surgery.
- Disadvantages: Infliximab can cause serious side effects, including infections (such as tuberculosis), lymphoma, and other cancers. It can also cause liver damage, heart failure, and allergic reactions. It requires intravenous administration, which can be inconvenient for some patients.

Vedolizumab:
- Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective integrin blocker that has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It has a good safety profile and is less likely to cause serious infections compared to other biologics.
- Disadvantages: Vedolizumab may not work as quickly as other biologics, and it may not be as effective in patients who have previously failed other biologic therapies. It also requires intravenous administration.

Please note that the choice of therapy should be individualized based on the patient's specific circumstances, including disease severity, comorbidities, lifestyle, and personal preferences. The patient should also be closely monitored for side effects and response to therapy.

INTRODUCTION
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the

some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates

usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse

Ulcerative colitis is a chronic, idiopathic, potentially
disabling condition that is clinically characterised
by bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus.1
Ulcerative colitis most commonly presents during the
third and fifth decades of life, and is associated with an

economic burden.2,3
Nearly 20 years ago, the advent of anti-tumour necrosis
factor biologics (eg, infliximab, adalimumab, and
golimumab) revolutionised therapeutics for ulcerative
colitis, enabling better disease control in terms of
increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission,
and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality
of life. Biologics with other targets were later approved
for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis,
